required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Revealing the Mechanisms by Which Milk Sugars Exaggerate Postprandial Lipaemia

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to determine to what extent ingestion of free sugars influence postprandial triglyceridaemia in men and women.

detailed_description.textblock: Each participant will undergo three experimental trials in a randomized, crossover research design. On each study day, participants will consume a test drink containing standardised amounts of carbohydrate and fat followed by collection of blood and breath samples to assess metabolic responses during the 6 hour postprandial period. Trials will be identical except for the type of carbohydrate contained within the test drink: 1) maltodextrin (glucose polymer), 2) lactose (galactose-glucose disaccharide) and 3) sucrose (fructose-glucose disaccharide).

primary_outcome.measure: Postprandial changes in plasma triglyceride concentrations
primary_outcome.description: Incremental area under the curve (iAUC) of plasma triglyceride concentrations

secondary_outcome.description: Time course for synthesis of fatty acids from non-lipid precursors using stable isotope methodology
Time course for whole-body dietary fatty acid oxidation using stable isotope methodology

secondary_outcome.measure: Postprandial changes in plasma insulin concentrations
secondary_outcome.description: Incremental area under the curve (iAUC) of plasma insulin concentrations

secondary_outcome.measure: Postprandial changes in plasma glucose concentrations
secondary_outcome.description: Incremental area under the curve (iAUC) of plasma glucose concentrations

secondary_outcome.measure: Postprandial changes in plasma galactose concentrations
secondary_outcome.description: Incremental area under the curve (iAUC) of plasma galactose concentrations

secondary_outcome.measure: Postprandial changes in plasma fructose concentrations
secondary_outcome.description: Incremental area under the curve (iAUC) of plasma fructose concentrations

secondary_outcome.measure: Postprandial changes in plasma VLDL-rich triglyceride [Svedberg flotation rate (Sf): 20-400] concentrations
secondary_outcome.description: Incremental area under the curve (iAUC) of plasma VLDL-rich triglyceride [Svedberg flotation rate (Sf): 20-400] concentrations

secondary_outcome.measure: Postprandial changes in plasma chylomicron-rich triglyceride (Sf: >400) concentrations
secondary_outcome.description: Incremental area under the curve (iAUC) of plasma chylomicron-rich triglyceride (Sf: >400) concentrations

secondary_outcome.measure: Postprandial changes in plasma lactate concentrations
secondary_outcome.description: Incremental area under the curve (iAUC) of plasma lactate concentrations

secondary_outcome.measure: Postprandial changes in plasma non-esterified fatty acid concentrations
secondary_outcome.description: Incremental area under the curve (iAUC) of plasma non-esterified fatty acid concentrations

secondary_outcome.measure: Postprandial changes in plasma beta-hydroxybutyrate concentrations
secondary_outcome.description: Incremental area under the curve (iAUC) of plasma beta-hydroxybutyrate concentrations

secondary_outcome.measure: Postprandial changes in plasma uric acid concentrations
secondary_outcome.description: Incremental area under the curve (iAUC) of plasma uric acid concentrations

arm_group.description: Glucose polymer; a common sugar substitute

intervention.description: Co-ingestion of maltodextrin with a high fat meal
Co-ingestion of sucrose with a high fat meal
Co-ingestion of lactose with a high fat meal

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
â€¢ Age: 18-50 years and premenopausal (for women)
Exclusion criteria:
- Weight instability (>5 kg change in body mass within last 6 months)
- Diagnosis of any form of diabetes
- Intolerances or allergies to any of the study procedures (e.g. lactose intolerance)
- Galactose disorders (e.g. galactokinase deficiency, UDPgalactose-4-epimerase deficiency, galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency)
- Fructose malabsorption
- Inborn errors of fructose metabolism (e.g. fructokinase deficiency, aldolase B deficiency, fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase deficiency)
- Pregnant or lactating
- Any condition that could introduce bias to the study (e.g. diagnoses of lipid disorders, including cardiovascular disease, or therapies that alter lipid or glucose metabolism, such as statins or niacin).

facility.name: Department for Health, University of Bath

patient_data.ipd_description: Raw data will be made available online upon publication in a peer-reviewed journal.
